CYCLIZINE

  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Nausea, Vomiting, Vertigo, Motion sickness, Labyrinthine disorders,

By intravenous injection or by intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    50 mg up to 3 times a day, for motion sickness, take 1–2 hours before departure.
  • For adults
    50 mg 3 times a day.

Nausea and vomiting of known cause, Nausea and vomiting associated with vestibular disorders and palliative care,

By continuous intravenous infusion or by subcutaneous infusion

  • For children 1 month–5 years
    0.5–1 mg/kg up to 3 times a day (max. per dose 25 mg), intravenous injection to be given over 3–5 minutes, for motion sickness, take 1–2 hours before departure.
  • For children 6–11 years
    25 mg up to 3 times a day, intravenous injection to be given over 3–5 minutes, for motion sickness, take 1–2 hours before departure.
  • For children 12–17 years
    50 mg up to 3 times a day, intravenous injection to be given over 3–5 minutes, for motion sickness, take 1–2 hours before departure.
  • For children 2–5 years
    12.5 mg up to 3 times a day.
  • For children 6–11 years
    25 mg up to 3 times a day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    50 mg up to 3 times a day.
  • For children 1 month–1 year
    3 mg/kg, dose to be given over 24 hours.
  • For children 2–4 years
    50 mg, dose to be given over 24 hours.
  • For children 6–11 years
    75 mg, dose to be given over 24 hours.
  • For children 12–17 years
    150 mg, dose to be given over 24 hours.

Nausea and vomiting associated with palliative care,

By mouth

  • For adults
    150 mg, dose to be given over 24 hours.
  • For adults
    50 mg up to 3 times a day.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Manufacturer advises avoid; however, there is no evidence of teratogenicity.

The use of sedating antihistamines in the latter part of the third trimester may cause adverse effects in neonates such as irritability, paradoxical excitability, and tremor.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Avoid in severe liver disease—increased risk of coma.

Contra indications

  • Avoid in Acute porphyrias (some antihistamines are thought to be safe)
  • neonates: neonate (due to significant antimuscarinic activity) in neonates

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Drowsiness,

rare: Anaphylaxis, angioedema, angle-closure glaucoma, arrhythmias, blood disorders, bronchospasm, confusion, convulsions, depression, dizziness, extrapyramidal effects, hypersensitivity reactions, hypotension, liver dysfunction, palpitation, paradoxical stimulation (especially with high doses in children) in children, paradoxical stimulation (especially with high doses in the elderly) in adults, photosensitivity reactions, rashes, sleep disturbances, tremor,

notKnown: Antimuscarinic effects, blurred vision, dry mouth, gastro-intestinal disturbances, hallucinations, headache, hypertension, movement disorders, oculogyric crisis, paraesthesia, psychomotor impairment, tachycardia, transient speech disorders, twitching, urinary retention,

Specific side effects

rare: transient paralysis,

notKnown: local irritation,

In adults

Elderly patients are more susceptible to side-effects.

In children

Children are more susceptible to side-effects.

In adults

Drowsiness is a significant side-effect with most of the older antihistamines although paradoxical stimulation may occur rarely, especially with high doses or in children and the elderly. Drowsiness may diminish after a few days of treatment and is considerably less of a problem with the newer antihistamines.

In children

Drowsiness is a significant side-effect with most of the older antihistamines although paradoxical stimulation may occur rarely in children, especially with high doses. Drowsiness may diminish after a few days of treatment and is considerably less of a problem with the newer antihistamines.

Directions for administration

In children

For administration by mouth, tablets may be crushed.

With subcutaneous use

Mixing and compatibility for the use of syringe drivers in palliative care

Cyclizine may precipitate at concentrations above 10 mg/mL or in the presence of sodium chloride 0.9% or as the concentration of diamorphine relative to cyclizine increases; mixtures of diamorphine and cyclizine are also likely to precipitate after 24 hours.

Advice for patients and carers

Cautions regarding administration

  • Epilepsy
  • : glaucoma in children
  • may counteract haemodynamic benefits of opioids
  • neuromuscular disorders—increased risk of transient paralysis with intravenous use
  • : prostatic hypertrophy in adults
  • pyloroduodenal obstruction
  • severe heart failure—may cause fall in cardiac output and associated increase in heart rate, mean arterial pressure and pulmonary wedge pressure
  • : susceptibility to angle-closure glaucoma in adults
  • urinary retention

Unlicensed use

In children

Tablets not licensed for use in children under 6 years.

Injection not licensed for use in children.

Prepared medicinal forms of CYCLIZINE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: suppository, oral suspension, oral solution,
Tablet
Solution for injection
